text:
MELISSA ALLEN: I
worked at Lion Apparel.
We had a sewing factory.
POPPY HARLOW: The big factory?
MELISSA ALLEN: Yeah.

POPPY HARLOW: Were you making
a pretty good income there?

MELISSA ALLEN: I
done decent there.
POPPY HARLOW: Yeah.

MELISSA ALLEN: One of the
only decent paying jobs left.

POPPY HARLOW: Better
than you are now?
MELISSA ALLEN: Yeah.

POPPY HARLOW: But when
that factory shuttered?
MELISSA ALLEN: I did too.
I mean, honestly.
[music playing]

MELISSA ALLEN: I've lived
here my entire life.

I've lived in poverty
my entire life.
So there's really no hope.

POPPY HARLOW: You're
young, Melissa.
MELISSA ALLEN: I know.
POPPY HARLOW: None?

MELISSA ALLEN: Every week, you
gotta rob Peter to pay Paul.
I've had my electric shut off.
I've had my water shut off.

You just gotta do
what you can do.
That's all you can do.

POPPY HARLOW: How is it to get
by living here in Beattyville?
MELISSA ALLEN: I work two jobs.

POPPY HARLOW: Two jobs?
MELISSA ALLEN: Yes.

POPPY HARLOW: You work
here at the gas station.

MELISSA ALLEN: Tuesday,
Wednesdays, and Thursdays.

And Friday, Saturday,
and Sunday, I work
a Cliffview cleaning cabins.

POPPY HARLOW: For
people watching

that have no idea
what it's like--

no idea-- what do you
want them to know?

Because I think that people
have an image of poverty,

and they don't
think it's someone
who works two full time jobs.
MELISSA ALLEN: Right.

I would just like
anybody that doesn't--

let them try to live on just
a basic 40-hour week at $7.25
after taxes and everything.
It's impossible.
It's impossible.

POPPY HARLOW: What
gets you by every day?
MELISSA ALLEN: Hayden.
POPPY HARLOW: Yeah, right?

MELISSA ALLEN: The
love of my child.

That's what-- at the
end of the day, that's
what-- it's all worth it.

So sometimes, you sit and
think, why do I have to do this?

And then at the end
of the day, when

you get all kinds of lovings,
that's what makes it worth it.

I don't want him to
ever struggle like I do.

I mean, I don't want him
to grow up and move away,

but I don't want him
to stay here either,
because there's nothing here.

And I've been here
my entire life.
My whole family lives here.
This is all I know.

But I don't want
him to be that way.

POPPY HARLOW: Do you
get a sense that people

here are more hopeful now
because of the new president?

MELISSA ALLEN: It
seems like people are.

But it's kind of almost
like wishing on lost hope,

because it's been
this way for so long--

I mean, as long as I
can remember, you know?
So I hope it gets better.
I really do.

But I just-- I don't want
to live on false hope.

POPPY HARLOW: You're realistic.
You're a mom.
MELISSA ALLEN: Yeah.

POPPY HARLOW: That's what
we have to be, right?
MELISSA ALLEN: Yep.
